Award.AwardTitle: Observations Relevant to Cometary Hyperactivity (The Year of 46P/Wirtanen)
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the fall of 2018, the very bright, very active comet 46P/Wirtanen will share the sky with two other bright comets, 21P/Giacobini-Zinner and 64P/Swift-Gehrels, as they reach their closest approach to the sun. Comet 46P/Wirtanen will be especially bright. The investigators will collect images and spectra of these three small comets whose orbits are controlled by Jupiter's presence. The observations during their passages near the sun this year will provide future studies with significant data to quantify compositions and physical characteristics of gases and dust around the comet, investigate the presence of icy grains, and determine common aspects or key differences among the comets. These observations are time critical as these good observing conditions will not present themselves again for over a decade for comet 21P, and more than two decades for comets 46P and 64P. The investigators will share their interpretations of the measured cometary activity, as well as the expected stunning and informative images of these comets, with the broader community through various public talks.

Unlike the hyperactive comet 46P, most Jupiter-family comets display a level of activity that can be accounted for by sublimation from a small fraction of their surface area. Comet 103P/Hartley 2 (the target of the NASA space probe Deep Impact), on the other hand, is a representative member of a hyperactive population that, paradoxically, exhibit active fractions > 100%. During its flyby of Hartley 2, Deep Impact observed a large carbon dioxide jet, suffused with small grains of water ice, originating from one lobe of the comet. The carbon dioxide escaping from the nucleus likely dragged subsurface water-ice grains into the coma. Once in the coma, the distributed ice grains dramatically increased the surface area for water vapor sublimation, explaining Hartley 2's hyperactivity. This model suggests that hyperactive comets are governed by subsurface volatiles with low sublimation temperatures that entrain ice grains to produce anomalously high-water production rates. Since the Deep Impact measurements, however, no other hyperactive comet has been sufficiently observed to confirm the applicability of the Hartley 2 model; this will change with observations of 46P.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We proposed to observe and collect visible images and near-infrared spectral data of three contemporaneous small and bright Jupiter-family comets (46P/Wirtanen, 21P/Giacobini-Zinner, and 64P/Swift-Gehrels) throughout their 2018 geometrically well placed perihelion passages such that future studies have these noteworthy data to quantify coma compositions and physical characteristics, investigate the presence of icy grains, and determine common observables or key differences among the comets to support the model of Hartley 2's hyperactivity, and if needed suggest refinements to the model. The hyperactivity model hypothesizes that small comets with large water production rates compared to their nucleus size must have two sources of water, one reservoir subliming directly from the nucleus and the other a population of icy grains drug into the coma by other volatiles escaping the nucleus and sublimating once in the coma.

The Lowell Discovery Telescope (LDT) was the main telescope utilized for this project, with observations planned and carried out in all semesters when the objects were available in the northern sky (namely Fall 2018 and Spring 2019), resulting in 10 nights of observations for comet 46P/Wirtanen, 9 for 21P/Giacobini-Zinner, and 8 for 64P/Swift-Gehrels.  LDT, a 4.3 meter telescope equipped with a visible imager with a set of cometary narrowband filters, is the largest telescope on which to collect cometary data in these filters to study coma composition, variability, and spatial distribution.  LDT also has a near-infrared spectrograph with which to examine the presence of ice in the coma and the color slope of the cometary dust.  With the collection of these data and all calibration data needed to systematically reduce them, we have a wealth of data to share with the community for comparative cometology and have greatly increased the amount of data available for 64P.

Although this grant only supported the collection of the data, compelling results on the rotational period of comet 46P/Wirtanen have already been derived from the data set and are evidence that future studies will similarly bear interesting results.
